items.headline: S&P 500 Dips, Dow Edges Up as Markets Absorb Inflation Data and Sector Rotations
items.summary: U.S. equities experienced a mixed close on Friday, February 13, ahead of the Presidents' Day holiday, with major indices reacting to a softening inflation report and continued sector rotations. While encouraging inflation and jobs data offered some calm, concerns about AI competition led to weakness in certain tech segments. Overall market sentiment points to a continued shift away from large-cap tech toward value, foreign equities, and defensive sectors. Not financial advice.

items.statContext: Declined last week, leaving it essentially unchanged for 2026.
The biggest loser among major indices last week, with the Nasdaq composite slipping 0.2% on Friday, February 13.
Rose 48 points on Friday, February 13, closing at 49,503 points.

items.headline: Magna International Soars on Strong Earnings
items.summary: Magna International Inc. ($MGA) surged after reporting better-than-expected fourth-quarter financial results and issuing optimistic FY26 guidance.

items.headline: Rivian Drives Higher
items.summary: Rivian Automotive Inc. ($RIVN) saw significant gains over the past week, with potential catalysts from recent announcements.

items.headline: Astera Labs Falls Post-Earnings
items.summary: Astera Labs, Inc. ($ALAB) declined sharply after reporting its fourth-quarter financial results.

items.headline: Pinterest Disappoints with Q4 Results
items.summary: Pinterest, Inc. ($PINS) experienced a significant drop following worse-than-expected fourth-quarter financial results and a weak first-quarter sales outlook.

items.headline: Inflation Cools, Jobs Grow, but Public Sentiment Lags Market Gains
items.summary: U.S. consumer inflation moderated to 2.4% year-over-year in January, down from 2.7%, and 130,000 jobs were created, exceeding expectations. The unemployment rate fell to 4.3%. Despite strong macroeconomic indicators, public sentiment on the economy remains subdued, particularly among those without stock holdings.

items.headline: Defensive and 'Old Economy' Sectors Gain Traction Amid Tech Pullback
items.summary: A notable rotation is occurring, with defensive sectors like Utilities (+7% last week), Real Estate, and Materials outperforming. Financials were a significant laggard, down nearly 5%. There is a visible shift away from the 'Magnificent 7' tech giants and into value, foreign stocks, and 'old economy' sectors like Transportation, driven by concerns over AI competition and a strong manufacturing outlook.

items.headline: Fed Holds Rates Steady, Eyes Future Cuts as Powell's Term Nears End
items.summary: The Federal Reserve maintained the federal funds rate at 3.50%-3.75% in January, following three consecutive cuts last year. Traders are now pricing in a significant chance of rate cuts by April and June. President Trump's nomination of Kevin Warsh to succeed Jerome Powell as Fed Chair, whose term ends May 15, 2026, could signal a shift in monetary policy approach.

items.headline: Q4 Earnings Season Nearing End, Focus Shifts to Upcoming Reports
items.summary: The fourth-quarter earnings season is winding down, with 57 S&P 500 companies still slated to report. The blended earnings growth rate for Q4 improved to 13.2% year-over-year. Major companies like Walmart, Deere, Analog Devices, and Booking Holdings are scheduled to release earnings in the week ahead (Feb 16-20).
